title: Scotland’s 28-24 loss to Japan in 1989 still ranks as one of the most humiliating days in Scottish rugby history
text:
It may have happened over 30 years ago, but Scotland’s 28-24 loss to Japan in Tokyo in 1989 still ranks as one of the most humiliating days in Scottish rugby history. Yet despite being the Brave Blossoms’ first Tier One victims it rarely merits a mention, because Scotland, like all major rugby nations, refused to award caps against sides like Japan. With such Tests relegated to the status of so-called non-cap internationals, the official records show that Scotland have won all seven of their encounters against Japan.
